description.narrative: Insatsen syftar till att stödja 8 länder i Afrika söder om Sahara att genomföra en analys av gällande lagstiftning och rättsväsende med fokus på hur väl dessa överensstämmer med de åtaganden länderna gjort i olika internationella deklarationer och protokoll. Syftet är därmed att främja ett rättsväsende som stödjer prevention mot hiv och aids och som är i linje med grundläggande mänskliga rättigheter.

The contribution aims at supporting 8 countries in Sub- Saharan Africa (SSA) to do an analysis of their current legislation and its implementation with a view to assess how well these harmonize with the commitments the countries have made in various international declarations. This will promote a legal environment that supports the prevention of HIV and AIDS and in line with funamental humna rights

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: During 2015, the Project provided strategic policy support to the African Union Commission (AUC), and three regional economic communities (RECs): the East African Community (EAC), the Economic Community of the West African States (ECOWAS), and the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and its Parliamentary Forum (SADC-PF). Regionally the Project also supported the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) Act of 2012 that was finally assented to by all Heads of States and Governments in East African Community and it also provided support to the African Commission on Human and Peoples’ Rights (ACHPR) to conduct a study titled ‘HIV, the law and human rights in the African human rights system: Key challenges and opportunities for rights-based Responses to HIV’ – the first such Africa-wide study under the AU to be completed in 2016.
-In 2015, the Project continued to support sensitizing key stakeholders on issues of HIV, human rights and the key populations. A dialogue on stigma and discrimination among the government, civil society, people living with HIV (PLHIV) networks, the media and other stakeholders was organised in Mozambique, a dialogue between the national AIDS council (NAC), the Zambia Human Rights Commission (ZHRC) and key population groups in Zambia resulted in a working arrangement between the NAC and ZHRC to ensure that the ZHRC addresses rights violations among key populations; and the first sub-National interaction to sensitize ‘court users committees’ and junior judiciary in Kenya on issues of key populations and human rights was supported. The Second meeting of the Africa Regional Judges’ Forum on HIV and Human Rights was attended by 23 judges from 13 countries and a database containing case law, judgements, scientific information pertaining to HIV and key populations was launched by the Forum and is being used widely. 2015 also saw the first regional meeting on Transgender People, HIV, Health and Human Rights in Africa convened and attended by 45 participants from key institutions from 6 countries in Africa. Over the three years of the project; results are evident within all 19 countries where either interim milestones or results can be achieved. The Project strengthened the capacity of regional, national governments, civil society and community based structures, putting in place the legal environments that respect rights of LGBTI and women and girls and key populations as an on-going process; with positive gains in some countries and interim milestones being achieved in others. These results have ranged from national parliaments considering changes in the national law (DR Congo, Chad); national AIDS councils incorporating findings from LEAs into new national strategic plans for HIV to prioritize key population interventions with clear indicators (Nigeria, Zambia); to developing and prioritizing action plans to take forward the LEA recommendations (Tanzania).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
